p: MR provides an exciting opportunity, because it can imitate an RCT. The underlying principle is that genetic variants associated with different concentrations of a drug target act in the same way the corresponding drug does ( Evans and Davey Smith, 2015). The SNPs essentially mimic lifelong exposure to low levels of a drug, and the random allocation of genes at birth is similar to randomization in an RCT. In addition, patients do not typically know their genotype, so MR studies are effectively blinded. Figure 2 visualizes the analogy between MR and an RCT, using serum urate and Parkinson’s disease as an example.
